CSS.title: Relative Paths in HTML and CSS
CSS.content:
When you use a path like `assets/logo.svg` in your HTML, the browser starts looking from the current document's location.

**Path Examples:**
- `./` or no prefix = current directory
- `../` = parent directory (go up one level)
- `/` = root directory

**From styles.scss to reference assets:**
```scss
// Go up one level to project root, then into assets
background-image: url('../assets/hero-image.png');
```

**Example Structure:**
```
project-root/
  ├── index.html
  ├── assets/
  │     └── hero-image.png
  └── scss/
        └── styles.scss
```

Relative paths make your links work correctly regardless of where your site is hosted.

CSS.title: SCSS Attribute Selectors
Markdown Heading Hierarchy
CSS.content:
Hashtags (#) in Markdown files represent headings in a hierarchy system:

**Heading Levels:**
- `#` = H1 (main title, biggest)
- `##` = H2 (second biggest)
- `###` = H3
- `####` = H4
- `#####` = H5
- `######` = H6 (smallest heading)

**Example Structure:**
```md
# Project Title
## Getting Started
### Installation
#### Prerequisites
```

The hierarchy creates a logical document structure/outline. Each additional `#` represents a deeper level in the document hierarchy.

CSS.title: CSS Padding Shorthand - Block and Inline
CSS.content:
You can use multiple-value shortcuts in the `padding-block` and `padding-inline` properties:

**Block Padding (vertical):**
```scss
padding-block: $space-2x $space-1x;
// top-bottom
```

**Inline Padding (horizontal):**
```scss
padding-inline: $space-3x $space-2x;
// left-right
```

The values assigned will be:
- **Block**: top-bottom
- **Inline**: left-right

CSS.title: Inline Styles Scope
CSS.content:
Inline styles only affect the specific element where they're applied, not other instances.

**Example:**
```html
<!-- Page 1 -->
<footer>...</footer>

<!-- Page 2 -->
<footer style="background-color: blue;">...</footer>
```

The blue background only appears on Page 2's footer.

**Advantages:**
- High specificity for one-off overrides
- Only affects the exact element

**Disadvantages:**
- Can't be reused easily
- Increases code duplication
- Generally discouraged for common styling patterns

Inline styles are fine for truly one-off changes that won't be repeated.

CSS.title: Browser Image Caching
CSS.content:
When an image is loaded on initial page visit, the browser caches it. Subsequent pages using the same image load it from cache.

**Benefits:**
- Image loads instantly on subsequent views
- Reduces bandwidth for server and user
- Improves page load performance

**How it works:**
If multiple pages use `assets/logo.png`, the browser downloads it once and reuses the cached version on other pages with identical URL paths.

CSS.title: CSS :has() Selector
CSS Grid with auto-fit and minmax()
CSS.content:
Create responsive layouts without media queries using `repeat()`, `auto-fit`, and `minmax()`.

**Example:**
```css
.grid {
  display: grid;
  grid-template-columns: repeat(auto-fit, minmax(500px, 1fr));
  gap: 1rem;
}
```

**How it works:**
- `repeat()` - Shorthand instead of writing `1fr 1fr 1fr...`
- `auto-fit` - Creates as many columns as will fit
- `minmax(500px, 1fr)` - Each column is min 500px, max 1fr

**Example Behavior:**
- Container 1200px wide → 2 columns at 600px each
- Container 1800px wide → 3 columns at 600px each
- Container <500px wide → 1 column (minimum treated as suggestion)

`auto-fit` automatically adjusts column count based on available space.

CSS.title: CSS clamp() Function
CSS.content:
The `clamp()` function sets a value within a min-max range.

**Syntax:**
```css
clamp(minimum, preferred, maximum)
```

**How it works:**
- Browser tries to use the "preferred" value
- If preferred is too small, use minimum
- If preferred is too large, use maximum

**Example - Fluid Typography:**
```css
h1 {
  font-size: clamp(1.5rem, 5vw, 3rem);
}
```

**Benefits:**
- Fluid typography in one line
- No media queries needed
- Responsive scaling based on viewport

CSS.title: Handling Large Words on Small Viewports
CSS.content:
Strategies for managing text overflow on smaller screens: **1. Word Break Tag:** ```html

Pneumonoultramicroscopic

``` The `` tag creates optional break points within words. **2. CSS word-break:** ```css .text { word-break: break-all; } ``` Makes lines end exactly at the edge, even splitting words across lines. Use these techniques to prevent horizontal scrolling on mobile devices.

CSS.title: Flex Property Shorthand
CSS.content:
`flex: 1` is shorthand for three properties:

```css
.item {
  flex: 1;
  /* Expands to: */
  flex-grow: 1;    /* Can grow to fill space */
  flex-shrink: 1;  /* Can shrink if needed */
  flex-basis: 0;   /* Starting size is 0 */
}
```

**Visual Example:**
```
┌─────────────────┐
│ header          │ ← Takes content height
├─────────────────┤
│                 │
│ main (flex: 1)  │ ← GROWS to fill space
│                 │
├─────────────────┤
│ footer          │ ← Gets pushed to bottom
└─────────────────┘
```

`flex: 1` tells an item to consume all leftover space, pushing other items to edges.

CSS.title: Accessibility - Hiding Duplicate Content
CSS.content:
When duplicating content for visual effects, hide duplicates from assistive technologies. **Use aria-hidden:** ```html
Content
Content
``` **When to use:** - Decorative elements - Animation duplicates - Visual UI enhancements This prevents screen readers from announcing duplicate content.

CSS.title: Non-Breaking Space Entity
CSS.content:
The ` ` entity prevents line breaks at specific points. **Example:** ```html

We turn raw data into measurable business growth and key insights

``` **Result:** Even when text wraps, "business" and "growth" stay together as one unit. **When to use:** - Keep related words together - Prevent awkward line breaks - Maintain semantic groupings **Warning:** Don't abuse it or lines might split at odd points.
